newsitem.title: HONG KONG: TENNIS-JOHANSSON CONTINUES HOT STREAK IN HONG KONG OPEN.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-JOHANSSON CONTINUES HOT STREAK IN HONG KONG OPEN.

text.p: Sweden's Thomas Johansson, the hottest player on the circuit with 14 straight victories, reached the semifinals of the Hong Kong Open on Friday with two wins in five hours.

Johannson, whose ranking has jumped from 60 to 39 thanks to back-to-back successes in Copenhagen and St Petersburg, sailed past American Jim Grabb 6-1 6-2 in his second round match and then defeated another American, 20-year-old Justin Gimelstob, 6-4 6-4 in the quarter-finals.
"I played really well today and kept the run going," said 22-year-old Johansson, the fourth seed. "It was a tough match against Gimelstob and I was lucky to win the break points."

Johansson will play top seed and two-time Hong Kong Open winner Michael Chang in the semifinals. The Chinese-American, who enjoys great support in Hong Kong, finished off his rain-delayed second round match against compatriot Jeff Tarango 6-4 4-6 6-1 and then beat seventh-seed David Prinosil of Germany 6-1 7-6 (7-5) in the quarter-finals.
"Thomas (Johannson) is definitely on a high," said Chang, winner here in 1994 and 1995. "I have never played him but when you are up against a Swede it is always going to be tough."

The other semifinal will be between fifth seeded Australian Patrick Rafter, who booked his place with a near faultless 6-3 6-1 win over Davis Cup teammate Todd Woodbridge, and qualifier Brian MacPhie of the United States.

MacPhie, ranked a lowly 308th in the world, defeated the unseeded Sebastien Lareau of Canada 6-3 6-3 in the last eight after causing an upset in the second round earlier in the day when he beat the number two seed, Marc Rosset of Switzerland, 7-6 (7-2) 6-2.

"If I serve well I can frustrate players," said MacPhie after reaching his first ATP Tour semi-final. "This could be a real jump start for my singles career. If I keep playing the way I have been, I can do alright against Pat (Rafter)."
